questions.text: End diastolic volume increases with:

Increase in negative intrathoracic pressure as it would increase the venous return.

questions.text: Which of the following brain regions is being stimulated in an experiment to control intractable pain?

choices.text: Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase increases its activity.

questions.text: The principal enzymes controlling glycogen metabolism— glycogen phosphorylase and glycogen synthase. Which of the following statements is inaccurate?
questions.solution:
The principal enzymes controlling glycogen metabolism— glycogen phosphorylase and glycogen synthase—are regulated in opposite directions by allosteric mechanisms, subcellular localization, and covalent moî€¶ification by reversible phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of enzyme protein in response to hormone action .

Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase increases its activity;
Phosphorylation of glycogen synthase reduces its activity.
Phosphorylation is increased in response to cyclic AMP (cAMP) formed from ATP by adenylyl cyclase at the inner surface of cell membranes in response to hormones such as epinephrine, norepinephrine, and glucagon.

cAMP is hydrolyzed by phosphodiesterase, so terminating hormone action; in liver insulin increases the activity of phosphodiesterase.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 168.

choices.text: Nanocrystals exhibit a narrow difference between their excitation and emission peak spectra

questions.text: All of the following are benefits of nanotechnology, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Nanocrystals, such as quantum dots, generally have a broad difference between their excitation and emission peak spectra, not a narrow one. This property, known as the Stokes shift, allows for efficient separation of excitation and emission signals, making them highly useful in imaging and sensing applications.

Nanotechnology has found tremendous application in the diagnosis of cancers because of all of the following advantages except
d)nanocrystals exhibit a narrow difference between their excitation and emission peak spectra.

To be used as fluorescent probes in biological 
staining and diagnostics, semiconductor
nanocrystals were created. 
The nanocrystals are photochemically stable
and feature a narrow, controllable, symmetric
emission spectrum compared to conventional
fluorophores.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 715.

questions.text: Test to differentiate the chromosome of normal and cancer cells:
questions.solution:
Test to differentiate the chromosome of normal and cancer cells is
b) comparative genomic hybridization

The entire DNA specimen from the sample of interest is labeled in one color and the normal control DNA specimen is indicated by another color. These are mixed in equal amounts and hybridized to normal metaphase chromosomes. The colour ratio is analyzed which determines where the DNA of interest may have: gains or losses of material.

questions.text: What causes hyperacute rejection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Preformed antibodies
 
  • Hyperacute rejection is mediated by preformed antibodies specific for antigens on graft endothelial cells.
  • The preformed antibodies may be natural IgM antibodies specific for blood group antigens or may be antibodies specific for allogeneic MHC molecules that were induced by prior exposure of the organ recipient to allogeneic cells through blood transfusions, pregnancy, or transplantation of another organ.

questions.text: On what does flow cytometry take place?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient of more than 70 years, presented with generalized lymphadenopathy, WBC count was 20,000/mm3 and blood film showed >70% mature looking lymphocytes. Next investigation that should be done:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Peripheral Immunophenotyping
 
  • The above clinical features are suggestive of CLL (Chronic lymphocytic leukemia).
  • Immunophenotyping will eliminate the other T-cell disorders and can often help sort other B-cell malignancies.
  • CLL/SLL has a distinctive immunophenotype- The tumor cells express the pan B-cell markers CD19 and CD20, as well as CD23 and CD5, the latter a marker that is found on a small subset of normal B cells. Low-level expression of surface Ig (usually IgM or IgM and IgD) is also typical, as is high-level expression of BCL2.
  • If Flow cytometry was in the option it would have been a better answer 
Plan of action : -
Acute Leukemia- Bone Marrow Aspiration 
CML - FISH
CLL- Flow cytometry 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 597.

questions.text: What is a side effect of HAART therapy that affects the eyes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Uveitis
 
  • Uveitis is one of the ocular side effects of the HAART therapy.
  • A study conducted in Indian children infected with HIV found a high prevalence of ocular and systemic lesions most commonly anterior uveitis followed by CMV retinitis.
  • An enhancement of immune function and a resultant decrease in systemic and ocular complications of HIV is the desired action of HAART. This improved immune function may result in intraocular inflammation, called “immune recovery uveitis” (IRU), leading to vision-limiting complications.
Online Reference: Dash S, Mohanty SK, Mohanty G. Ocular Complications in Patients on Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy: A Case Report. Cureus. 2023 Oct 18;15(10):e47242. doi: 10.7759/cureus.47242. PMID: 38022310; PMCID: PMC10654452.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Rho kinase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fasudil 
Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, such as fasudil, ripasudil, and netarsudil, target the ROCK pathway, influencing smooth muscle contraction, fibrosis, and cellular motility. They are primarily used in treating glaucoma (reducing intraocular pressure) and cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage. They also show potential for pulmonary hypertension, fibrosis, cancer, and neurological recovery. Side effects include conjunctival hyperemia and hypotension.
  • Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm in experimental animals. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests. It is investigational in angina.
  • Fasudil appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH. Surgical treatment for advanced disease includes creation of a right atrial to left atrial shunt and lung transplantation.

Option 2 Ranolazine is a novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride block ENaCs in the luminal membrane of principal cells in late distal tubules and collecting ducts by binding to a site in the channel pore.
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: Which is the best agent for premenstrual syndrome management?

choices.text: Decreasing interaction of drug with target proteins

questions.text: Where does the issue occur in the design of new drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increasing drug interaction with non-target proteins.


Drug design, often referred to as rational drug design is the inventive process of finding new medications based on the knowledge of a biological target.

  • A successful drug with a protein target must bind to its target with high affinity so that even a small dose of the drug will yield a blood concentration high enough to bind a large fraction of the targeted protein.
  • If the affinity were low, then a high concentration of drug would be needed for a substantial fraction of the target sites to be occupied, and a large dose of drug would need to be administered, leading to inconvenience and an increased risk of side effects.
  • The affinity of a small molecule for a protein is generally given as the dissociation constant, the concentration of free drug molecules in solution at which 50% of the targeted protein has bound drug, the lower this concentration, the higher the affinity
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 88.

questions.text: Cholinomimetic is not used for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Bradycardia

Cholinomimetic is not used for bradycardia. They might be used for;
    • ï¿²open angle glaucoma
    • ï¿²cobra bite
    • ï¿²myasthenia gravisï¿²

* [Extra Edge]:
 
  • ACh hyperpolarizes the SA nodal cells and decreases their rate of diastolic depolarization. As a result, rate of impulse generation is reduced, bradycardia or even cardiac arrest may occur.
  • At the A-V node and His-Purkinje fibres refractory period (RP) is increased and conduction is slowed: P-R interval increases and partial to complete A-V block may be produced. The force of atrial contraction is markedly reduced and RP of atrial fibres is abbreviated.
A tip to remember this is to understand Atropine(Anticholinergic) is the DOC for most of bradycardia. Hence automatically cholinergic & antiadrenergic will cause bradycardia. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 114.

questions.text: Which of the following gram-negative bacteria's endotoxin does not contribute to the pathogenesis of the natural disease?

questions.text: Aerosol spread leading to epidemics is seen in infection with:

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does not apply to both "T cells" and "B cells"?

Class I MHC is present in both T cells and B cells have additionally Class II MHC. Both have antigen specific receptors.

questions.text: High fever, discomfort, intestinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting, diarrhoea, and hypotension are the symptoms that the farmer exhibits. Which stain is going to aid in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Watson's stain will help in it's diagnosis

The clinical features are suggestive of bubonic plague. It is caused by yersinia pestis.
Yersinia pestis is best demonstrated by polychromatic stains like wayson's stain and wright-giemsa stain.
Bubonic plague is the most common variety of the disease. It is named after the buboes meaning swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite. Other clinical features include sudden onset of fever and chills, headache and fatigue.

On staining with Giemsa stain or methylene blue (Wayson's stain), the bacteria has bipolar staining with two ends densely stained and the central area clear. This is the characteristic "Safety pin appearance" seen in yersinia pestis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 325.

questions.text: A young man with known history of heroin addiction is brought in the emergency in an unconscious state by friends. On examination his pupil are pin point. What will be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) IV naloxone
 
  • Heroine is diacetylmorphine. In case of opioid overdose IV Naloxone is used as treatment of choice.
  • Naloxone is the drug of choice for morphine poisoning (0.4–0.8 mg i.v. every 2–3 min: max 10 mg) and for reversing neonatal asphyxia due to opioid use during labor (10 µg/kg in the cord).

questions.text: A woman assaulted by a neighbour was brought to you in the emergency department with a fracture of the middle tooth. The injury was extended medially to the mouth where there was also a contusion to the bilateral leg. What in the nature of the injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Grievous injury

The nature of injury is grievous hurt.
Because Sixth clause of Sec 320 IPC(Grievous hurt) constitutes fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth as grievous hurt.
The following kinds of hurt only are designated as "grievous"-
First.—Emasculation.
Secondly.—Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
Thirdly.—Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
Fourthly.—Privation of any member or joint.
Fifthly.—Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint.
Sixthly.—Permanent disfiguration of the head or face.
Seventhly.—Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.
Eighthly.—Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of twenty days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 292.

questions.text: If a disease has a very low prevalence when compared to its incidence, it suggests:
questions.solution:
If the prevalence is very low as compared to the incidence of disease it implies disease is very fatal or it is easily curable.

Prevalence=incidence × duration
If the prevalence is very low then either incidence is low or duration is short and duration is short if the disease is easily curable or very fatal.

questions.text: The pattern of change of disease trends of mortality and morbidity where the pandemics infection are replaced by degenerative and man-made disorders as the main cause of morbidity and the most frequent cause of fatality is known as:
questions.solution:
The pattern of change of disease trends of mortality and morbidity where the pandemics infection are replaced by degenerative and man-made disorders as the main cause of morbidity and most frequent cause of fatality is known as epidemiological transition.
  • The epidemiologic transition describes changing patterns of population distributions in relation to changing patterns of mortality, fertility, life expectancy, and leading causes of death.
  • The burden of disease pattern of developed, developing high mortality, and developing low mortality countries in the world differ substantially. This phenomenon reflects what is known as the “epidemiological transition’.
  • As life expectancy increases, the major causes of death and disability in general shift from communicable, maternal and perinatal causes to chronic, non-communicable ones.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 35.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (3) 75% premium borne by the family. This is a false statement. 75% of premium is borne by Central Government - not by the family as given in the option.

RSBY- The Scheme
  • RSBY has been launched by Ministry of Labour and Employment, Government of India to provide health insurance coverage for Below Poverty Line (BPL) families.
  • The objective of RSBY is to provide protection to BPL households from financial liabilities arising out of health shocks that involve hospitalization.
Eligibility
Unorganized sector workers belonging to BPL category and their family members (a family unit of five) shall be the beneficiaries under the scheme.
The beneficiaries will be issued smart cards for the purpose of identification.

Benefits
The State Governments are advised to incorporate at least the following minimum benefits in the package / scheme:
1. The unorganised sector worker and his family (unit of five) will be covered.
2. Total sum insured would be Rs. 30,000/- per family per annum on a family floater basis.
3. Cashless attendance to all covered ailments
4. Hospitalization expenses, taking care of most common illnesses with as few exclusions as possible
5. All pre-existing diseases to be covered
6. Transportation costs (actual with maximum limit of Rs. 100 per visit) within an overall limit of Rs. 1000.

Funding Pattern
1. Contribution by Government of India: 75% of the estimated annual premium of Rs. 750.
2. Contribution by respective State Governments: 25% of the annual premium, as well as any additional premium.
3. The beneficiary would pay Rs. 30 per annum as registration/renewal fee.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 719.

questions.text: What do the lowest mode and highest mean indicate?
questions.solution:
Highest mean and lowest mode indicates positive skewing.

Sequence of decreasing trend of central tendencies in case of positive skewed distribution is:
  • Mean>median>mode
Sequence of increasing trend of central tendencies in case of negative skewed distribution is:
  • Mean<median<mode



In both of these, the mode is simply the most frequently occurring score (the highest point on the curve); the mean is pulled up or down by the influence of a relatively small number of very high or very low scores; and the median lies between the two, dividing the distribution into two equal areas under the curve.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 9.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man has anterior lenticonus and ESRD now. His maternal uncle also died of a similar illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Triad seen in Alport's syndrome:

  2. ï¿²sensorineural deafness
  3. ï¿²ocular abnormalities(anterior lenticonus)ï¿²
 
  • Classically, patients with Alport’s syndrome develop hematuria, thinning and splitting of the GBMs, and mild proteinuria (<1–2 g/24 h), which appears late in the course, followed by chronic glomerulosclerosis leading to renal failure in association with sensorineural deafness.
  • Some patients develop lenticonus of the anterior lens capsule, “dot and fleck” retinopathy, and rarely, leiomyomatosis.
  • Approximately 85% of patients with Alport’s syndrome have an X-linked inheritance of mutationsin the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome Xq22–24.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2346, 2347.

questions.text: Which of the following is the SARS causative agent?
questions.solution:
SARS causative agent is corona virus.

questions.text: What is a blink reflex used for?
questions.solution:
Blink reflex is used for mid-pontine lesions.
 
  • Corneal blink reflex has its centre @ level of Mid-Pons.
  • So any lesion involving Mid-pons will have abnormal/absent Blink reflex.

A neurophysiological test known as the BRT is used to assess the brainstem reflex circuits.

questions.text: Grisel syndrome all are true except:
questions.solution:
For grisel syndrome all are true except 4. no need for neurosurgeon

Grisel syndrome is a rare condition characterized by non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation (partial dislocation between the first and second cervical vertebrae) following an infection or inflammation in the head and neck region. It is most commonly associated with upper respiratory tract infections, such as pharyngitis or tonsillitis, but can also occur after surgical procedures like tonsillectomy or adenoidectomy.

Causes:
Grisel syndrome is thought to result from laxity of the ligaments that stabilize the atlantoaxial joint, which can be caused by inflammation spreading to this area from nearby infections.

Symptoms:
- Neck pain and stiffness
- Limited or painful neck movement (especially rotation)
- Head tilted to one side (torticollis)
- Swelling or tenderness around the neck
- Neurological symptoms (rare in early stages but can occur if the spinal cord becomes compressed)

Diagnosis:
- Clinical evaluation based on history of recent upper respiratory infections or surgeries
- Imaging studies like X-rays, CT scans, or MRI to confirm atlantoaxial subluxation

Treatment:
- Conservative treatment in mild cases with immobilization of the neck using a cervical collar and anti-inflammatory medications.
- Antibiotics to treat the underlying infection.
- In more severe cases or if neurological symptoms are present, traction or surgery may be required to realign the vertebrae and stabilize the joint.

Early diagnosis and treatment are critical to avoid long-term complications, including permanent neurological damage. Therefore, Early intervention by a Neurosurgeon can be necessary




Reference: Dhingra's Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 8th edition, Page no 507, 508.
Bucak, Abdulkadir et al. “Grisel's Syndrome: A Rare Complication following Adenotonsillectomy.” Case reports in otolaryngology vol. 2014 (2014): 703021. doi:10.1155/2014/703021. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3982280/

questions.text: Except for_____, all of the following are observed in cervical syringomyelia:
questions.solution:
2. hypertrophy of abductor pollicis brevis

In case of cervical syringomyelia muscle wasting is seen in:
  • ï¿²Lower back
  • ï¿²Shoulders
  • ï¿²Arms and handsï¿²
And not the hypertrophy of abductor pollicis brevis
 
  • The presentation is a central cord syndrome consisting of a regional dissociated sensory loss (loss of pain and temperature sensation with sparing of touch and vibration) and areflexic weakness in the upper limbs.
  • The sensory deficit has a distribution that is “suspended” over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms (cape distribution) or in the hands.
  • Most cases begin asymmetrically with unilateral sensory loss in the hands that leads to injuries and burns that are not appreciated by the patient.
 
  • As the cavity enlarges and compresses the long tracts, spasticity and weakness of the legs, bladder and bowel dysfunction, and Horner’s syndrome appear



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3453.

questions.text: Which of the following describes a temporal arteritis feature?
questions.solution:
Giant cell arteritis among following is a feature of temporal arteritis.
 
  • Giant cell arteritis, historically referred to as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium- and large-sized arteries.
  • It characteristically involves one or more branches of the carotid artery, particularly the temporal artery.
  • However, it is a systemic disease that can involve arteries in multiple locations, particularly the aorta and its main branches.
  • Clinical features include- Headache, Jaw claudication, Amarausis fugax. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2811.

questions.text: A 70-year-old retired military person with good previous medical record complains of bi-temporal headache forlast 3 weeks which is decreased in lying down position. He states that he gets relief by giving pressure over bilateral temples. The patient also complains of loss of appetite with feeling feverish. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is chronic tension headache.
 
  • The term tension-type headache (TTH) is frequently used to refer to a persistent head-pain syndrome characterised by tight, band-like discomfort on both sides of the head.
 
  • The pain typically builds slowly, fluctuates in severity, and may persist more or less continuously for many days. The headache may be episodic or chronic (present >15 days per month). 
 
  • The pain of TTH can generally be managed with simple analgesics such as acetaminophen, aspirin, or NSAIDs. Behavioral approaches including relaxation can also be effective.


â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹
Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3365.

choices.text: X-ray of cervical area of neck in flexion and extension

questions.text: A patient of rheumatoid arthritis develops sudden onset quadriparesis, Babinski sign was positive, increased muscle tone of limbs with exaggerated tendon jerks and worsening of gait with no sensory, sphincter involvement. The best initial investigation is:
questions.solution:
The initial investigation is X-ray of cervical area of neck in flexion and extension.

 
  • The next inquiry to be performed in rheumatoid arthritis patients with compressive myelopathy or neurological dysfunction is an X-ray of the cervical area of the neck in flexion and extension
  • However, the best investigation to diagnose Compressive myelopathy is MRI Spinal cord with or without contrast.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2759, 3450.

questions.text: Which of the following examinations is useful in determining the site of a misplaced implant in a patient with an implanted cardiac pacemaker (defibrillator)?
questions.solution:
In a patient with  implanted cardiac pacemaker (defibrillator), the investigation useful to know the position of the misplaced implant is X-ray
 
  • Lead dislodgement maybe radiographically visible or it maybe a micro dislodgement, where there is no radiographic change in position, but there is significant increase in pacing threshold or decline in electrogram amplitude.

A plain radiograph/X-Ray is the modality of choice to determine the location of implantable cardioverter defibrillator. 
  • CXR allows visualization of ICD leads and the generator with its position relative to the heart. It can also detect if there are any complications such as Lead dislodgement or migration.
  • CT scan or Fluoroscopy is used if detained analysis of the pacemaker is required, however CXR is the most effective way and the first line investigation to locate an ICD.


Hence, Best method to know the position and integrity of ICD is plain radiograph.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1914.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about type 1 renal tubular acidosis?

  • ï¿²Citrate is generally tolerated better than sodium bicarbonate and can be given as the potassium or sodium salt. depending on the severity of hypokalemia.ï¿²



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2291-2294.

questions.text: An elderly female presents with the nasal blockade and nasal discharge with black debris. Blood sugar was raised and urine is positive for ketones. Best treatment for the patient would be:

Best treatment for the patient is amphotericin B

The peri-orbital region and vision impairment are involved in the mucormycosis that this diabetic patient most certainly has, according to the most recent research. questions.text: What does a thromboembolic event involving gait apraxia show?
questions.solution:
Gait apraxia is seen in thromboembolic episode involving ACA.

Anterior cerebral artery mainly supplies frontal lobe and it's occlusion leads to gait apraxia.

Signs and symptoms: Structures involved [ACA lesion]:
 
  • Paralysis of opposite foot and leg: Motor leg area
  • A lesser degree of paresis of opposite arm: Arm area of cortex or fibers descending to corona radiata
  • Cortical sensory loss over toes, foot, and leg: Sensory area for foot and leg
  • Urinary incontinence: Sensorimotor area in paracentral lobule
  • Contralateral grasp reflex, sucking reflex, gegenhalten (paratonic rigidity): Medial surface of the posterior frontal lobe; likely supplemental motor area
  • Abulia (akinetic mutism), slowness, delay, intermittent interruption, lack of spontaneity, whispering, reflex distraction to sights and sounds: Uncertain localization- probably cingulate gyrus and medial inferior portion of frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes
  • Impairment of gait and stance (gait apraxia): Frontal cortex near leg motor area
  • Dyspraxia of left limbs, tactile aphasia in left limbs: Corpus callosum



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3327.

Beta-Thalassemia:

questions.text: A patient with Tubercular meningitis was taking ATT regularly. At end of 1 month of regular intake of drugs deterioration in the sensorium is noted in the condition of the patient. Which of the following investigations is not required on emergency evaluation?
questions.solution:
CSF examination in this case is not required in emergency evaluation.

  • NCCT followed by MRI and LFT will be useful for immediate diagnosis or status of the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be determined by a USG in a patient with a surgical cause of obstructive jaundice?

questions.text: A tumor was detected on histopathological examination of a child who underwent resection and anastomosis for an insusceptible small intestinal mass. Which among the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 3. Lymphoma

Most likely tumor associated is lymphoma
M/c tumor of small bowel in children is lymphoma and it can lead to intussusception.

Carcinoid tumors generally present with more chronic symptoms, like diarrhea, flushing, and, in rare cases, carcinoid syndrome.
Villous adenomas are rare in children and typically affect the colon rather than the small intestine.
Sarcomas can also affect the small intestine, but they are less common than lymphoma in pediatric patients. They may present as a mass, and while they can be aggressive, lymphoma is still the more common diagnosis in this clinical context.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 260.

questions.solution:
True about buerger's disease is b) neural involvement is present

buerger's disease is a segmental inflammatory disease affecting small and medium sized arteries and veins in upper and lower extremities and the inflammatory process involves neighbouring veins and nerves.

* Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger’s disease):
  • This is characterised by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized limb arteries, thrombophlebitis of superfcial or deep veins and Raynaud’s syndrome; it usually occurs in young male smokers.
  • Histologically, there are infammatory changes in the walls of arteries and veins, leading to thrombosis.
  • Treatment is total abstinence from smoking, which arrests, but does not reverse, the disease. Established arterial occlusions are treated as for atheromatous disease, but amputations may eventually be required.

questions.text: A female patient has had lower abdominal pain and amenorrhea for the past eight weeks. A lateral adnexa with a lump and thick endometrium was discovered on USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Possible diagnosis in a female with 8 weeks of amenorrhea, pain in the left lower abdomen, and thick endometrium with a mass in the lateral adnexa on an ultrasound is ectopic pregnancy.

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.
 
  • The classic triad is amenorrhea that is followed by pain and vaginal bleeding.
  • With tubal rupture, lower abdominal and pelvic pain is usually severe and frequently described as sharp, stabbing, or tearing. Some degree of vaginal spotting or bleeding is reported by most women with tubal pregnancy.

Endometrial findings in TVS:
  1. With ectopic pregnancy, a trilaminar endometrial pattern is characteristic.
  2. First, a pseudosac is a fluid collection between the endometrial layers and conforms to the cavity shape. If a pseudosac is noted, the risk of ectopic pregnancy is increased.
  3. Second, a decidual cyst is identified as an anechoic area lying within the endometrium but remote from the canal and often at the endometrial–myometrial border. Tis may represent early decidual breakdown that precedes cast formation.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 221-223.

questions.text: A female patient diagnosed with amenorrhea two months ago complained of sudden abdominal pain with an adnexal mass and a positive urine pregnancy test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis is ectopic pregnancy.

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.
 
  • The classic triad is amenorrhea that is followed by pain and vaginal bleeding.
  • With tubal rupture, lower abdominal and pelvic pain is usually severe and frequently described as sharp, stabbing, or tearing. Some degree of vaginal spotting or bleeding is reported by most women with tubal pregnancy.
  • An initial urine β-hCG assay, urinalysis, and measure of hemoglobin or hematocrit are routine. A complete blood count (CBC) to assess the white blood cell count may be preferred if serious inî€¹ection is a possible diagnosis. A positive urine pregnancy test result should prompt a serum β-hCG assay for those with pain or bleeding. In ectopic pregnancy, increase in serum beta-hCG after 48 hours is less than 66%.

Endometrial findings in TVS:
  1. With ectopic pregnancy, a trilaminar endometrial pattern is characteristic.
  2. First, a pseudosac is a fluid collection between the endometrial layers and conforms to the cavity shape. If a pseudosac is noted, the risk of ectopic pregnancy is increased.
  3. Second, a decidual cyst is identified as an anechoic area lying within the endometrium but remote from the canal and often at the endometrial–myometrial border. This may represent early decidual breakdown that precedes cast formation.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 221-223.

choices.text: Anatomical difference between right and left side
Difference in blood supply to both sides
Right handedness is more common in the population

questions.text: Which of the following reasons is false for a study that discovered that the right ovary ovulates more than the left?
questions.solution:
All are possible explanation for the cause except that Option 3: Right handedness is more common in population
It is thought that right-sided predominance was either inherited or resulted from variations in the ovarian vasculature.
 
  • In a study conducted, it was seen that For both fertile and infertile women ovulation from the right ovary occurred more often than from the left ovary (55 versus 45%; P: < 0.005).
  • The ratio of pregnancies from right-sided ovulation (approximately 64%) per total number of pregnancies was higher than that of right-sided ovulation (approximately 55%) during non-pregnant cycles (P: < 0.0001).
  • Mid-luteal serum oestradiol and testosterone were higher (P: < 0.05) in right-sided ovulation than left-sided.
  • Taken together, in both fertile and infertile women the fertility potential of oocytes from the right ovary surpasses that of the left ovary.


Reference: Fukuda, M et al. “Right-sided ovulation favours pregnancy more than left-sided ovulation.” Human reproduction (Oxford, England) vol. 15,9 (2000): 1921-6. doi:10.1093/humrep/15.9.1921. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10966987/

questions.text: Which of the following treatments should be given to a patient complaining of a copious vaginal discharge and pruritus, although there is no cervical discharge on speculum examination?

  • Therefore, This patient should be treated for both ï¿²Bacterial Vaginosis and Candidiasis with Metronidazole and fluconazole.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 329-331.

questions.text: Which of the following is least common in uterine fibroid?
questions.solution:
Sarcomatous change is least seen in uterine fibroid. Because risk of fibroid uterus developing from sarcoma is 0.5% and is the least common secondary change.
 

Here’s a brief summary of the common types of fibroid degeneration:

  1. Hyaline Degeneration:

    • Most common type (up to 60% of cases).
    • Fibroid tissue becomes glassy and homogeneous due to protein deposition.

  2. Cystic Degeneration:

    • Results from further progression of hyaline degeneration.
    • Leads to the formation of fluid-filled cystic spaces within the fibroid.

  3. Red (Carneous) Degeneration:

    • Typically occurs during pregnancy.
    • Caused by venous thrombosis and hemorrhage within the fibroid, leading to acute pain and red discoloration of the tissue.
    • C/f- abdominal pain, increased ESR, leukocytes and fever. 
    • Differential diagnosis is torsion of fibroid- severe abdominal pain but no fever or leukocytosis. 

  4. Calcific Degeneration:

    • Occurs in older women.
    • Calcium deposits form within the fibroid, making it hard and gritty.

  5. Fatty Degeneration:

    • Rare.
    • Involves the accumulation of fat within fibroid cells.

  6. Sarcomatous Degeneration:

    • Extremely rare (<1% of cases).
    • Represents malignant transformation into leiomyosarcoma.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 160.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not occur in a healthy pregnancy but is present in a patient with heart disease?
questions.solution:
Distended neck veins are seen in pregnancy with heart disease.

Distended neck veins are seen in pregnancy with heart disease, but not seen in normal pregnancy.

Because of heart disease mainly right sided heart failure increased jugular venous pressure upto + 5cm is seen due to high cardiac output causing neck vein distension.

Supine hypotension is a condition that develops in late pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the I.V.C when the patient is supine.As a result, hypotension is generated. 

Exertional dyspnea :-Pregnancy causes a state of hyperventilation,which is most likely caused by progesterone's effects on the respiratory center and the center's increased sensitivity to carbon dioxide. The woman feels her breath getting shorter. 

Pedal edema also seen due to decreased colloidal osmotic tension due to hemodilution.


Clinical indicators of heart disease during pregnancy are:

ï¿²Cyanosis
ï¿²clubbing of fingers
ï¿²Persistent neck vein distention
ï¿²Systolic murmur grade 3/6 or greater
ï¿²Diastolic murmur
ï¿²Cardiomegaly
ï¿²Persistent arrhythmia

questions.text: A 30y old lady with history of two LSCS now came with history of painless bleeding PV at 34 weeks of gestation. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Most likely diagnosis in this case is placenta previa ( History of Painless bleeding PV).
  • Because ï¿²the history of previous C-section or  ï¿²the presence of any scar on uterus is a predisposing factor for placenta previa.
 
  • Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta is located close to or covering the cervix, which can lead to painless vaginal bleeding in the third trimester. This condition is more common in women with a history of cesarean sections (LSCS) and often presents around the gestational age described here (34 weeks).

Other options: 

  1. Oligohydramnios refers to low amniotic fluid levels and does not typically cause painless bleeding.
  2. Pelvic tumor and
  3. Uterine anomalies might cause complications but are less likely to cause painless bleeding at this gestational age.

Placenta previa should be ruled out or confirmed via ultrasound in cases of third-trimester bleeding, especially with a history of previous C-sections.


 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 285, 288.

questions.text: A woman who has had a previous caesarean section arrives in labour. In which conditions are trials of conventional vaginal delivery not advised?
questions.solution:
Trial of labour after cesarean section (TOLAC) or Vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) is contraindicated in 3. Previous classical cesarean section

When there has been a previous traditional or inverted-T shaped uterine incision caesarean section, the attempt at a normal vaginal delivery is prohibited due to high chances of uterine rupture. 

Contraindications to TOLAC/VBAC:
1. Prior classic or T-shaped incision or other transmural uterine surgery
2. Contracted pelvis
3. Medical or obstetric complication that precludes vaginal delivery
4. Patient refusal
5. Inability to immediately perform emergency cesarean because of unavailable surgeon or anesthesia personnel, inadequate staff or facility

questions.text: A young woman complains of infertility as well as cyclical discomfort and dysmenorrheal symptoms. Which one of the following would be an option for her investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Diagnostic laproscopy

  • Infertility as well as cyclical discomfort and dysmenorrheal symptoms are suggestive of Endometriosis.
  • Laparoscopy is the gold standard in the diagnosis of endometriosis. TVS cannot detect endometriosis. 
  • The diagnosis should be validated by peritoneal and tissue biopsy because corpus luteal hematoma can resemble a chocolate cyst.

Role of laparoscopy: 

• To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
• Locate the site of endometriosis and staging
• To take biopsy.
• To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation and removal


Therefore, Laproscopy is considered a gold standard for diagnosis of endometriosis.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 178-180.

questions.text: In cases of haemorrhage, the shock index (HR/SBP) can be used to assess the level of bleeding. Which of the following best describes a serious PPH?
questions.solution:
0.9-1.1 is most indicative for significant PPH.

Shock index of more than 0.9 is a sign of tissue hypoperfusion.
 
  • The shock index (SI) is defined as the HR/systolic blood pressure (SBP) with a normal SI being 0.5–0.7.
  • An elevated SI (>0.9) has been proposed to be a more sensitive indicator of transfusion requirement and of patients with critical bleeding among those with hypovolemic (hemorrhagic) shock than either HR or BP alone.
  • The SI may also identify patients at risk for postintubation hypotension.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2238.

questions.text: A neurosurgeon dropped his kid to the school then there he saw a child with uncontrollable laughing and precocious puberty. When he again went to the school in  parents teachers meeting, he talked to the father of that boy and advised him to get an MRI done and the diagnosis was confirmed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis is Hypothalamic hamartoma.

Clinical features of children with hypothalamic hamartoma: ï¿²
  • Central precocious puberty starting before the age of 3 years ï¿²
  • Seizures, especially laughing spells (gelastic seizures)
 
  • Gelastic seizures are epileptic events characterized by bouts of laughter. Laughter-like vocalization is usually combined with facial contraction in the form of a smile.
 
  • Autonomic features such as flushing, tachycardia, and altered respiration are widely recognized. Conscious state may not be impaired, although this is often difficult to asses particularly in young children.
 
  • Gelastic seizures have been associated classically to hypothalamic hamartomas, although different extrahypothalamic localizations have been described.
 
  • Hypothalamic hamartomas are rare congenital lesions presenting with the classic triad of gelastic epilepsy, precocious puberty and developmental delay.



Reference: Téllez-Zenteno, José F et al. “Gelastic seizures associated with hypothalamic hamartomas. An update in the clinical presentation, diagnosis and treatment.” Neuropsychiatric disease and treatment vol. 4,6 (2008): 1021-31. doi:10.2147/ndt.s2173. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2646637/

choices.text: When vitamin D levels turn to normal
When growth plate healing is seen radio-graphically
When bone specific alkaline phosphatase is normal

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and has a foot deformity. When should a decision to undergo corrective surgery be made?
questions.solution:
According to Campbell Orthopedics - "The operation should be deferred until there is X-ray and other evidence that the rachitic process is over and that the osseous structures are normal"

Hence, corrective surgery should be undertaken when the growth plate healing is seen radiographically (option 2) - that is the best evidence of healing in rickets.  Presence of growth plate healing shows that endochondral ossification has normalized and bone remodeling can sustain the surgical correction.


Other options
  • Option 1 (Vitamin D levels normal): Not reliable because vitamin D can normalize biochemically before growth plates fully heal.
  • Option 3 (Bone-specific ALP normal): ALP is a marker of osteoblastic activity but may remain elevated for some time, even after healing has started. It is not used as the deciding factor for surgery.
  • Option 4 (Serum calcium normal): Calcium often normalizes quickly with supplementation, but deformity correction is deferred until radiographic healing is evident.

Reference-Campell Orthopedics 14th edition/ Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 112-114

questions.text: Which of the following has no shunt reversal during the disease's normal course?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 3.TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot).

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by four anatomical abnormalities:
1. Sub-pulmonic Stenosis
2. Right ventricular hypertrophy
3. Large unrestrictive VSD
4. Overriding of Aorta

The primary direction of blood flow in TOF is from right to left  due to the pulmonary stenosis (leading to R->L Shunt via the large VSD). This R->L Shunt leads to mixing of deoxygenated blood with oxygenated blood causing cyanosis. This will NOT reverse unless there's an intervention like surgery to relieve the stenosis. However, this is not part of the "normal course" of the disease but rather a result of treatment. 

In other options(ASD/VSD Or PDA - all are acynotic CHD) -normally there is L->R shunt but shunt reversal can happen which is called Eisenmenger syndrome. 

Hence, the only disease without shunt reversal is TOF.
 

Reference- Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 417-419

questions.text: A preterm infant with poor respiration at birth starts having seizures 10 hours after birth. What should be the epilepsy medication of choice?

ï¿²After 24 hours of loading dose, maintenance dosing can be started at 3-6 mg/Kg/day, usually administered in two separate doses.

questions.text: A child with hypoglycemia is not able to utilise glucose from glycogenolysis or gluconeogenesis. Which of the following enzymes does the child lack?
questions.solution:

A deficiency in this enzyme impairs the liver’s ability to release free glucose into the bloodstream, leading to hypoglycemia.
  • This condition is seen in Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (von Gierke's disease), where both glycogen breakdown and gluconeogenesis are impaired, resulting in severe fasting hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A child has seborrheic dermatitis, sinusitis, and chronic ear drainage. The child is found to be failing to thrive, with hepatosplenomegaly and exophthalmos. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Probable diagnosis is histiocytosis-X
  • Histiocytosis, also referred to as Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH), and formally called Histiocytosis X represents a group of rare disorders involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells which are resident macrophages in dermal tissue.
  • This condition is characterized by the abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells and can affect multiple organs, including the skin (seborrheic dermatitis), respiratory system (sinusitis, chronic ear infections), and cause failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and exophthalmos.
  • Diagnosis- Light microscopy shows cells with coffee bean nucleus, Electron microscopy shows Tennis Racket shaped granules.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of PDA in a preterm baby?
questions.solution:
Narrow pulse pressure is not a sign of PDA in a preterm baby.
  • Apnea: This is a common symptom in preterm infants with PDA due to respiratory distress and increased pulmonary blood flow.
  • Tachycardia: PDA can cause increased cardiac workload, leading to faster heart rates (tachycardia).
  • Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC): PDA can contribute to NEC due to gut hypoperfusion and increased shunting of blood.
  • Narrow pulse pressure: In PDA, there is often a wide pulse pressure due to the large difference between systolic and diastolic pressures (systolic pressure is high due to increased cardiac output, while diastolic pressure is low due to runoff of blood into the pulmonary circulation).


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 414-416

questions.text: Which of the following most frequently manifests as bilateral proptosis in children?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Leukemia

Bilateral proptosis in children is the most common presentation of leukemia.
  • The most frequent of the options given for the origin of bilateral proptosis in children is leukemic infiltration into the orbit (chloroma).
  • Orbital infiltration or mass formation can result in proptosis or diplopia.
  • In a study by Russo et al. evaluation of orbital and ocular manifestations in the recruited patients with acute childhood leukemia revealed that orbital or ocular lesions were noted more commonly in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) (66.6%) than in those with ALL (15.1%)

Reference: Sivaperumal, Pon Ramya et al. “Bilateral Proptosis in a Child: A Rare Presentation of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.” Journal of ophthalmic & vision research vol. 13,4 (2018): 511-513. doi:10.4103/jovr.jovr_2_16

questions.text: What is the most common complication after lens extraction in persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous?
questions.solution:
Most common complication after lens extraction in persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous is retinal detachment.

Both retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage are the complications of surgery in persistent hyperplasia primary vitreous.
But retinal detachment is more common as compared to vitreous haemorrhage.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 844, 845.

questions.text: For which of the following procedures is a laser uvulo pharyngo palatoplasty performed?
questions.solution:
Laser uvulopharyngopalatoplasty is a surgery done for snoring.

Laser uvulopharyngopalatoplasty is a appropriate treatment for following conditions:

questions.text: Absolute requirment for Cochlear implantation is functioning:
questions.solution:
Absolute requirment  for cochlear implantation is functioning auditory nerve.

In the cochlear kind of sensorineural hearing loss, where nerve fibres are still present and functional, cochlear implants are used.
Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of cochlea.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 138

questions.text: In which of the following is the third window effect seen?
questions.solution:
Third window effect is seen in dehiscent superior semicircular canal.

The superior semicircular canal's superior bone is absent, creating a third window into the membranous labyrinth and possibly a condition of vestibular and auditory complaints.
Reference : https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7477384/#:~:text=The%20most%20commonly%20occurring%20third,clinical%20audiological%20and%20vestibular%20tests

questions.text: What is pseudosulcus in the larynx?
questions.solution:
Pseudosulcus in larynx is seen in case of laryngopharyngeal reflux.

Laryngeal pseudosulcus, also known as pseudosulcus vocalis, can occur in people with laryngopharyngeal reflux. This sulcus, which is situated between the real vocal cords and the subglottic swelling, is thought to be caused by reflux-induced swelling in the subglottic area.

Reference : https://aao-hnsfjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1067/mhn.2002.125603#:~:text=diagnosis%20of%20LPR.-,CONCLUSIONS,of%20a%20diagnosis%20of%20LPR.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is high-frequency audiometry used?
questions.solution:
High frequency audiometry is used in ototoxicity.

Pure-tone hearing thresholds are measured using extended high-frequency audiometers between 8000 and 16000 Hz. Ahead of ototoxic changes, high frequency audiometry can offer early warning.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 36

questions.text: Which test is the most effective for evaluating a newborn's auditory function?
questions.solution:
Best test for evaluation of newborn auditory function is brainstem evoked auditory response(BERA) and for screening purpose of the auditory function of neonates is otoacoustic emissions.

Following are the uses of otoacoustic emissions:
ï¿²Screening test of hearing in neonates
ï¿²Help to differentiate between cochlear and retrocochlear lesions
ï¿²Used to diagnose retrocochlear pathologies especially auditory neuropathy

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 29

questions.text: What is the initial mechanism of action of intra-tympanic gentamicin given for the treatment of Meniere's disease:
questions.solution:
Gentamicin, when administered via trans-tympanic injection, primarily affects vestibular type I and type II hair cells while sparing the cochlear inner and outer hair cells. This makes it a vestibulotoxic drug. 

Gentamicin targets the transport channels (Na+ K+ ATPase) on vestibular hair cells, allowing it to accumulate in these cells and lead to their death, thereby alleviating vertigo symptoms without compromising hearing, as it does not impact inner and outer hair cells or the stria vascularis. It's noteworthy that vestibular type I hair cells are particularly susceptible to damage from Gentamicin.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 115

questions.text: What treatment should be given to a patient with asymptomatic macules and an erythematous, painless lesion over the glans with generalised lymphadenopathy?
questions.solution:
• Treatment of choice in this condition is benzathine penicillin.
  • A young man with generalised lymphadenopathy and asymptomatic macules, papules, and a reddish patch across his palate, as well as a flat, moist lesion on his glans penis, all suggestive of syphilis.
  •  Injection Benzathine penicillin is first line of treatment for syphilis.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 29.25

questions.text: A 50 y patient has an oral ulcers and skin bullae that are taking their time to heal. Where exactly is the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The lesion is suprabasal.
  • A 50-year-old patient with bulla on his body and oral mucosa with the given image likely has pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Bulla in pemphigus vulgaris is intra-epidermal and the split is suprabasal.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: A man experiences recurring urticaria after being in the sun and exercising. What could be the possible diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis in this case is cholinergic utricaria.
  • The man experiences recurring urticaria after being in the sun and exercising, which is consistent with the symptoms of cholinergic urticaria.
  • Acetyl choline, which is released by post-ganglionic cholinergic enervated sweat glands in response to any stimulus that causes sweating by raising core body temperature, develops cholinergic urticaria.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 42.11

questions.text: What is kinemyography used for?
questions.solution:
Kinemyography is used for monitoring of neuromuscular function.

It utilizes a bending sensor that is placed between thumb and forefinger and the core of sensor is a piezoelectric material.


Reference-: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8103272/

questions.text: What is the benefit of EEG in anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Depth of general anesthesia

EEG in anesthesia is useful in: 
  • Depth of general anesthesia
  • In EEG during anesthesia the 16-lead is used to monitor the depth of general anesthesia.
  • It is also used to assess the sedation and awareness.

questions.text: Which grade does a patient who has hypertension under clinical treatment belong to?
questions.solution:
Above patient falls under ASA 2.

  • So, ASA grade in hypertensive patient whose BP is controlled, is 2.


Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status (PS) Classification System:

questions.text: Which part of the body is used to check the proper arterial supply using a modified Allen's test?
questions.solution:
Modified Allen's test is for checking the proper arterial supply at the wrist.
 
  • Modified Allen's test is used to know the integrity of palmar arch (patency of radial and ulnar arteritis).
  • A normal Modified Allen’s test or Barbeau test confirming dual blood supply to the hand from the radial and ulnar arteries is recommended prior to access at this site.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1860.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent analgesic agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nitrous oxide
 
  • Most potent analgesic agent among following is nitrous oxide.
  • Nitrous oxide has analgesic actions thought to be mediated by activation of opioid receptors in the periaqueductal grey of the midbrain.
  • This leads to modulation of nociceptive pathways through the release of norepinephrine and activation of α2−adrenoceptors in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
NOTE: Nitric oxide, CO2 and oxygen do not have any analgesic/anesthetic action. Only nitrous oxide is an anaesthetic amongst these. Hence, the answer by elimination. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 405.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle relaxants' dosages must be determined using the obese person's actual weight rather than his ideal weight?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atracurium
 
  • Dose of atracurium has to be calculated on the basis of total body weight of an obese person rather than its ideal weight.
  • Instead of using the optimal weight, the muscle relaxant atracurium must be calculated using the whole-body weight of an obese person.
  • This is because atracurium is eliminated by Hoffman's elimination, it is not dependent on liver or renal elimination, so ideal body weight is not required, actual bodyweight is required.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 380.

questions.text: A 4-year-old was intubated while being prepared for a craniotomy. Anesthesia equipment suddenly began to display bellows. What is the subsequent course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Start manual ventilation
Next management is to start manual ventilation with Bag and Mask, as this allows for immediate control of the patient's oxygenation and ensures patient safety during the surgery.
 
  • This condition in question is known as collapse of bellows.
  • Collapse of Bellows generally means there is a leak in the circuit, and basically that the tidal volume will not get delivered and the patient is not ventilated.
  • Next step would be quick assessment of any disconnections in the circuit and ruling out other causes of leak in the circuit while simultaneously ventilating manually till the cause of collapse of bellows is found.
  • Increasing flow rate or using a bigger tube in case of leak is not appropriate step.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2359.

questions.text: A newborn in need of intubation had respiratory distress. What is the quickest and most reliable way to verify intubation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Capnography
 
  • The fastest and most accurate method to confirm intubation is capnography.
  • Capnography is the monitoring of the concentration or partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the respiratory gases and it is known to be the surest confirmatory sign of correct intubation.
  • The most important and objective indicator of tracheal intubation, however, is the presence of a normal capnogram (carbon dioxide [CO2] waveform) for the presence of at least three breaths. Severe bronchospasm, equipment malfunction, cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse may prevent the appearance of a capnogram tracing despite proper ETT placement. If doubt remains, then flexible bronchoscopy, although not routinely used, is very reliable at confirming ETT placement.
  • In patients with adequate tissue perfusion, assess and confirm the location of the endotracheal tube using an end-tidal carbon dioxide detector (such as continuous waveform capnography, colorimetric capnography, or non-waveform capnography)

Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:
  • Detection of ETCO2 by Capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Bilaterally auscultated breath sounds
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Absence of epigastric breath sound
  • Visible mist in the ET tube
  • Large exhaled Tidal volume
  • Good compliance of reservoir bag during manual ventilation


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1308, 1309, 1392-1398.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about lidocaine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) It is most cardiotoxic local anesthetic 
 
  • All are true about lidocaine except: It is most cardiotoxic local anesthetic. Because bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic.
  • Bupivacaine is more prone to prolong QTc interval and induce ventricular tachycardia or cause cardiac depression.
* [Extra Edge]: Lidocaine
  • Injected around a nerve it blocks conduction within 3 min, whereas procaine may take 15 min; also, anesthesia is more intense and longer lasting.
  • Vasodilatation occurs in the injected area. It is used for surface application, infiltration, nerve block, epidural, spinal and intravenous regional block anesthesia.
  • Lidocaine 2% with or without adrenaline is the most popular dental anesthetic. Cross-sensitivity with ester LAs is not seen.
  • The early central effects of lidocaine are depressant, i.e. drowsiness, mental clouding, dysphoria, altered taste and tinnitus. Overdose causes muscle twitching, convulsions, cardiac arrhythmias, fall in BP, coma and respiratory arrest like other LAs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 392.

Dye is instilled percutaneously first then MRI is used

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate regarding how the MRCP should be used?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Use of heavily T2-weighted image without contrast to create the three dimensional image of the biliary tree using MIP algorithm

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)-
  • Non-invasive imaging technique to visualize the intra and extrahepatic biliary tree and pancreatic ductal system.
  • Provides diagnostically-equivalent images to ERCP  
  • Useful non-invasive technique in high risk patients preventing significant morbidity.
  • Utilizes fluid present in the biliary and pancreatic ducts as an intrinsic contrast medium by acquiring the images using heavily T2-weighted sequences.
  • The fluid-filled structures in the abdomen have a long T2 relaxation time as compared to the surrounding soft tissue
  • Therefore, these structures appear hyperintense against the surrounding non-fluid-containing tissues and therefore, can be easily distinguished. 
  • No exogenous contrast material is administered to the patient bile itself acts as the contrast. 
  


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 658.

questions.text: The most radiation-sensitive phase of the cell cycle is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: G2M
 
  • According to law of Bergonie and Tribondeau, Radiosensitivity is directly proportional to mitotic activity of cell and inversely proportional to differentiation. 
 
  • Summary of radiosensitivity of various tissues:
 
 
  • Phase of the cell cycle which is most sensitive to radiation is G2M.
  • Susceptibility sequence of different phases of cell cycle for for radiation is:
G2M>G2>M>G1>Early S>Late S Phase


NOTE- Most common organ affected due to radiation is skin. Among all the layers, Stratum basale is the most affected due to presence of actively dividing cells. 



Reference: Basic Radiotherapy Physics and Biology, 2014 edition, Page no 293.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman has been taking alendronate for seven years to treat her osteoporosis. She now complains of right thigh pain. What is the next investigation  to be carried out?
questions.solution:
The next investigation to be performed is X-Ray

A femoral shaft fracture could be the cause of right thigh pain in a 70-year-old female who has been on alendronate for osteoporosis treatment for seven years.
And this could be visualised on X-Ray.

Other options- 
  • Serum Vitamin D and ALP levels are normal in osteoporosis
  • DEXA scan is the IOC for osteoporosis. 


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1090.
Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 138, 139.

  • Applicable to mammography, ultrasound and MRI.

questions.text: What conditions is stereotactic surgery used to treat?
questions.solution:
Stereotactic surgery is used for treatment of brain tumor.

Stereotactic radiosurgery involves the delivery of a concentrated dose of radiation to a defined volume in the brain and is used for treatment of brain tumor.




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 722.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy struggles to do well on his ninth-grade exam. But he is incredibly intelligent and sharp. what is the best test to identify his issue?
questions.solution:
• Best test to diagnose his problem is specific learning disability test. (Option 3)
  • Triad of Specific Learning Disorders is: Dyslexia, Dysgraphia, and Dyscalculia.
  • Given that the child in the question is sharp and intelligent but not able to get good grades this image strongly suggests the presence of a "specific learning disability" disorder, which is best identified by a specific learning disability test.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1182-1184.

questions.text: During the night, a middle-aged man laments his inability to sleep. Which of the following methods allows one to determine how long a person is actually awake or asleep?
questions.solution:
• This can be ascertained by actigraphy.
  • Actigraphy is a non-invasive method of monitoring human rest/activity cycles
  • Sleep actigraphs are helpful for identifying circadian rhythms and sleep patterns.
  • A barograph is a device used to measure atmospheric pressure, while a kymograph is a device used to measure physiological responses such as muscle contractions or heart rate.
  • Plethysmography is a method used to measure changes in blood flow or volume in different parts of the body and is not directly related to sleep monitoring.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 562.

questions.text: A 50y old male started alcohol at 20 years, presently taking 3 quarters daily over 30 years, now complains that he gets the kick in 1 quarter, diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Reverse tolerance.
  • When a heavy drinker develops liver damage, the liver no longer generates as much of the enzymes required to break down alcohol in the body as it once did, resulting in reverse tolerance.
  • Reverse tolerance occurs when the body becomes more sensitive to the effects of a drug over time, even with lower doses
  • The Mellanby effect is the idea that people experience more intense alcohol intoxication symptoms when their blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is increasing than when it's decreasing even if the BAC is same in both cases.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 617

questions.text: When a psychiatric patient undergoes a mental status examination, the awareness of the disease is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Insight
 
  • Insight is an important element of a mental status examination and refers to an individual’s awareness and understanding of their mental illness.
  • Having insight regarding one's illness means that a patient is aware of their disorder and can accurately identify the symptoms that they are experiencing. It implies a level of awareness and understanding of their illness, as well as the potential effects of their disorder on their daily functioning.
  • Insight can be evaluated through direct questioning and observations of the individual's behavior. Without insight, individuals may be unaware of their symptoms and the need for treatment, making proper diagnosis and care more difficult.
  • Other options:
  • Orientation: State of awareness of oneself and one's surroundings in terms of time, place, and person. (Option 2)
  • Judgment: Mental act of comparing or evaluating choices within the framework of a given set of values for the purpose of electing a course of action. (Option 3)
  • Rapport: a relationship characterized by agreement, mutual understanding, or empathy that makes communication possible or easy (Option 4)


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1413, 1415.

questions.text: A child is not eating any vegetables. Every time he finishes the last vegetable in his diet, his mother starts giving him a chocolate. What's the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Operant conditioning 
 
  • The technique used in this case by the mother is known as operant conditioning.
  • In operant conditioning, a reward or punishment system is used to inculcate some specific behavior. In the given scenario, chocolates are used as rewards.
  • Operant conditioning is a type of learning in which behavior is strengthened or weakened by the consequences that follow it. In this scenario, the child's behavior of finishing a serving of vegetables is being reinforced by the reward of receiving a chocolate. This reward serves as a positive reinforcement, making it more likely that the child will repeat the behavior of finishing their vegetables in the future.
  • Classical conditioning is a learning process that occurs when two stimuli are repeatedly paired: a response which is at first elicited by the second stimulus is eventually elicited by the first stimulus alone.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 101-103.
